--- title: "Reproducibility and replicability" description: "Learn about the meaning of reproducible, replicable, robust and generalisable research" author: "Stefano Coretta" date: 2024-09-15 format: html: css: [webex.css] include-after-body: [webex.js] execute: warning: false --- ::: {.cell} ::: ::: callout-warning #### Prerequisites - [Research questions and hypotheses](research-qh.qmd) ::: [![](../img/reproducible-definition-grid.svg){fig-align="center" width="550"}](https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.3332807) ## Definitions The terms *reproducible* and *replicable* are often used interchangeably but The Turning Way has proposed a semantic scheme which introduces two more terms: *robust* and *generalisable*. Check out the section [Table of Definitions for Reproducibility](https://book.the-turing-way.org/reproducible-research/overview/overview-definitions#table-of-definitions-for-reproducibility) from [The Turing Way book](https://book.the-turing-way.org), which defines the four terms. ::: callout-note #### Quiz 1 **When is research not reproducible?**
::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"} #### Hint Research is **reproducible** when you can produce the same results using the original data and code/methods. Research is **replicable** when you can produce the same results using new data and the original code/methods. See . ::: :::
